title: Two Sum
description: Given an array of integers nums and an integer target, return indices of the two numbers such that they add up to target. You may assume that each input would have exactly one solution, and you may not use the same element twice. You can return the answer in any order.
constraints:
• 2 <= nums.length <= 10^4
• -10^9 <= nums[i] <= 10^9
• -10^9 <= target <= 10^9
• Only one valid answer exists
example_explanation: Because nums[0] + nums[1] == 9, we return [0, 1].
hints:
• Try using a hash map to store values you've seen
• For each number, check if target - number exists in the hash map
• The time complexity should be O(n)

title: Add Two Numbers
description: You are given two non-empty linked lists representing two non-negative integers. The digits are stored in reverse order, and each of their nodes contains a single digit. Add the two numbers and return the sum as a linked list. You may assume the two numbers do not contain any leading zero, except the number 0 itself.
constraints:
• The number of nodes in each linked list is in the range [1, 100]
• 0 <= Node.val <= 9
• It is guaranteed that the list represents a number that does not have leading zeros
example_explanation: The number 342 + 465 = 807, represented in reverse order as [7,0,8].
hints:
• Handle the carry carefully
• Don't forget to add a new node if there's a carry at the end
• Process both lists simultaneously

title: Longest Substring Without Repeating Characters
description: Given a string s, find the length of the longest substring without repeating characters.
constraints:
• 0 <= s.length <= 5 * 10^4
• s consists of English letters, digits, symbols and spaces
example_explanation: The answer is "abc", with the length of 3.
hints:
• Use sliding window technique
• Use a hash set to track characters in current window
• Move the left pointer when you encounter a duplicate

title: Median of Two Sorted Arrays
description: Given two sorted arrays nums1 and nums2 of size m and n respectively, return the median of the two sorted arrays. The overall run time complexity should be O(log (m+n)).
example_explanation: The merged array is [1,2,3] and median is 2.
hints:
• Use binary search on the smaller array
• Partition both arrays such that left half elements <= right half
• The median is found at the partition point

title: Longest Palindromic Substring
description: Given a string s, return the longest palindromic substring in s.
constraints:
• 1 <= s.length <= 1000
• s consist of only digits and English letters
example_explanation: Note: "aba" is also a valid answer.
hints:
• Expand around center approach
• For each position, try to expand palindrome
• Consider both odd and even length palindromes

title: Zigzag Conversion
description: The string PAYPALISHIRING is written in a zigzag pattern on a given number of rows, then read line by line. Write the code that will take a string and make this conversion given a number of rows.
constraints:
• 1 <= s.length <= 1000
• s consists of English letters (lower-case and upper-case), ',' and '.'
• 1 <= numRows <= 1000
example_explanation: Read line by line: PAH NAP LSI IIG YIR
hints:
• Create an array of strings for each row
• Iterate through the string and determine which row to add each character
• Use a direction flag to go up and down

title: Reverse Integer
description: Given a signed 32-bit integer x, return x with its digits reversed. If reversing x causes the value to go outside the signed 32-bit integer range [-2^31, 2^31 - 1], then return 0.
example_explanation: Reverse of 123 is 321.
hints:
• Handle negative numbers carefully
• Check for overflow before multiplying by 10
• Use modulo to get last digit

title: String to Integer (atoi)
description: Implement the myAtoi(string s) function, which converts a string to a 32-bit signed integer (similar to C/C++'s atoi function). The algorithm: Read in and ignore leading whitespace, check for sign, read in digits until non-digit or end of input, convert to integer and clamp to 32-bit range.
constraints:
• 0 <= s.length <= 200
• s consists of English letters (lower-case and upper-case), digits (0-9), ' ', '+', '-', and '.'
example_explanation: The first non-whitespace character is '4', followed by '2'. So the result is 42.
hints:
• Handle whitespace, signs, and non-digit characters carefully
• Check for overflow at each step
• Stop reading when you encounter a non-digit

title: Palindrome Number
description: Given an integer x, return true if x is a palindrome, and false otherwise.
example_explanation: 121 reads the same backward as forward.
hints:
• Negative numbers are not palindromes
• Reverse the second half and compare with first half
• No need to convert to string

title: Regular Expression Matching
description: Given an input string s and a pattern p, implement regular expression matching with support for '.' and '*' where: '.' Matches any single character, '*' Matches zero or more of the preceding element.
constraints:
• 1 <= s.length <= 20
• 1 <= p.length <= 30
• s contains only lowercase English letters
• p contains only lowercase English letters, '.', and '*'
example_explanation: '*' means zero or more of the preceding element 'a'. Therefore, by repeating 'a' once, it becomes "aa".
hints:
• Use dynamic programming
• dp[i][j] represents if s[0..i) matches p[0..j)
• Handle '*' by considering zero or more occurrences

title: Container With Most Water
description: You are given an integer array height of length n. There are n vertical lines drawn such that the two endpoints of the ith line are (i, 0) and (i, height[i]). Find two lines that together with the x-axis form a container, such that the container contains the most water. Return the maximum amount of water a container can store.
constraints:
• n == height.length
• 2 <= n <= 10^5
• 0 <= height[i] <= 10^4
example_explanation: The vertical lines are at indices 1 and 8, with heights 8 and 7. Area = 7 * 7 = 49.
hints:
• Use two pointers from both ends
• Move the pointer with smaller height inward
• Calculate area at each step and track maximum

title: Integer to Roman
description: Roman numerals are represented by seven different symbols: I, V, X, L, C, D and M. Given an integer, convert it to a roman numeral.
hints:
• Create a mapping of values to roman symbols
• Process from largest to smallest
• Handle special cases like 4, 9, 40, 90, 400, 900

title: Roman to Integer
description: Roman numerals are represented by seven different symbols: I, V, X, L, C, D and M. Given a roman numeral, convert it to an integer.
constraints:
• 1 <= s.length <= 15
• s contains only the characters ('I', 'V', 'X', 'L', 'C', 'D', 'M')
• It is guaranteed that s is a valid roman numeral in the range [1, 3999]
hints:
• Iterate from right to left
• If current value < previous value, subtract it
• Otherwise add it to result

title: Longest Common Prefix
description: Write a function to find the longest common prefix string amongst an array of strings. If there is no common prefix, return an empty string.
constraints:
• 1 <= strs.length <= 200
• 0 <= strs[i].length <= 200
• strs[i] consists of only lowercase English letters
example_explanation: The longest common prefix is "fl".
hints:
• Compare characters of first string with all others
• Stop when you find a mismatch
• Vertical scanning approach works well

title: 3Sum
description: Given an integer array nums, return all the triplets [nums[i], nums[j], nums[k]] such that i != j, i != k, and j != k, and nums[i] + nums[j] + nums[k] == 0. Notice that the solution set must not contain duplicate triplets.
example_explanation: The distinct triplets are [-1,0,1] and [-1,-1,2].
hints:
• Sort the array first
• Fix one element and use two pointers for remaining two
• Skip duplicates to avoid duplicate triplets

title: 3Sum Closest
description: Given an integer array nums of length n and an integer target, find three integers in nums such that the sum is closest to target. Return the sum of the three integers.
example_explanation: The sum that is closest to the target is 2 (-1 + 2 + 1 = 2).
hints:
• Similar to 3Sum, use sorting and two pointers
• Track the minimum difference
• Update result when closer sum is found

title: Letter Combinations of a Phone Number
description: Given a string containing digits from 2-9 inclusive, return all possible letter combinations that the number could represent. A mapping of digits to letters (just like on telephone buttons) is given.
constraints:
• 0 <= digits.length <= 4
• digits[i] is a digit in the range ['2', '9']
example_explanation: The digit 2 maps to "abc" and 3 maps to "def".
hints:
• Use backtracking to generate all combinations
• Build string character by character
• Use a map to store digit to letter mappings

title: 4Sum
description: Given an array nums of n integers, return an array of all the unique quadruplets [nums[a], nums[b], nums[c], nums[d]] such that nums[a] + nums[b] + nums[c] + nums[d] == target.
example_explanation: These are the unique quadruplets that sum to 0.
hints:
• Extension of 3Sum
• Fix two elements, use two pointers for remaining two
• Skip duplicates at all levels

title: Remove Nth Node From End of List
description: Given the head of a linked list, remove the nth node from the end of the list and return its head.
constraints:
• The number of nodes in the list is sz
• 1 <= sz <= 30
• 0 <= Node.val <= 100
• 1 <= n <= sz
example_explanation: Remove the 2nd node from the end, which is 4.
hints:
• Use two pointers with n nodes gap
• Move both pointers until fast reaches end
• Slow pointer will be at node before target

title: Valid Parentheses
description: Given a string s containing just the characters '(', ')', '{', '}', '[' and ']', determine if the input string is valid. An input string is valid if: Open brackets must be closed by the same type of brackets, Open brackets must be closed in the correct order, Every close bracket has a corresponding open bracket of the same type.
constraints:
• 1 <= s.length <= 10^4
• s consists of parentheses only '()[]{}'
example_explanation: All opening brackets have matching closing brackets in correct order.
hints:
• Use a stack to track opening brackets
• When you see closing bracket, check if it matches top of stack
• Stack should be empty at the end

title: Merge Two Sorted Lists
description: You are given the heads of two sorted linked lists list1 and list2. Merge the two lists into one sorted list. The list should be made by splicing together the nodes of the first two lists. Return the head of the merged linked list.
constraints:
• The number of nodes in both lists is in the range [0, 50]
• -100 <= Node.val <= 100
• Both list1 and list2 are sorted in non-decreasing order
example_explanation: Merge the two sorted lists.
hints:
• Use dummy node to simplify edge cases
• Compare values and attach smaller node
• Don't forget to attach remaining nodes

title: Generate Parentheses
description: Given n pairs of parentheses, write a function to generate all combinations of well-formed parentheses.
example_explanation: These are all combinations of 3 pairs of parentheses.
hints:
• Use backtracking
• Track count of open and close parentheses
• Add open if count < n, add close if close_count < open_count

title: Merge k Sorted Lists
description: You are given an array of k linked-lists lists, each linked-list is sorted in ascending order. Merge all the linked-lists into one sorted linked-list and return it.
constraints:
• k == lists.length
• 0 <= k <= 10^4
• 0 <= lists[i].length <= 500
• -10^4 <= lists[i][j] <= 10^4
• lists[i] is sorted in ascending order
example_explanation: Merge all lists into one sorted list.
hints:
• Use min heap to track smallest elements
• Add one node from each list to heap initially
• Extract min and add its next node to heap
topics: Linked List,Divide and Conquer,Heap (Priority Queue),Merge Sort

title: Swap Nodes in Pairs
description: Given a linked list, swap every two adjacent nodes and return its head. You must solve the problem without modifying the values in the list's nodes (i.e., only nodes themselves may be changed.)
constraints:
• The number of nodes in the list is in the range [0, 100]
• 0 <= Node.val <= 100
example_explanation: Swap nodes in pairs: (1,2) and (3,4).
hints:
• Use dummy node and track previous, current, and next nodes
• Swap two nodes at a time
• Update pointers carefully

title: Reverse Nodes in k-Group
description: Given the head of a linked list, reverse the nodes of the list k at a time, and return the modified list. k is a positive integer and is less than or equal to the length of the linked list. If the number of nodes is not a multiple of k then left-out nodes, in the end, should remain as it is.
constraints:
• The number of nodes in the list is n
• 1 <= k <= n <= 5000
• 0 <= Node.val <= 1000
example_explanation: Reverse every 2 nodes. Last node remains as is.
hints:
• Check if there are k nodes remaining
• Reverse k nodes using standard reverse technique
• Connect reversed group with previous and next groups

title: Remove Duplicates from Sorted Array
description: Given an integer array nums sorted in non-decreasing order, remove the duplicates in-place such that each unique element appears only once. The relative order of the elements should be kept the same. Return k after placing the final result in the first k slots of nums.
constraints:
• 1 <= nums.length <= 3 * 10^4
• -100 <= nums[i] <= 100
• nums is sorted in non-decreasing order
example_explanation: First two elements should be 1 and 2.
hints:
• Use two pointers: one for current position, one for next unique
• Compare adjacent elements
• Move unique elements to front of array

title: Remove Element
description: Given an integer array nums and an integer val, remove all occurrences of val in nums in-place. The order of the elements may be changed. Return k after placing the final result in the first k slots of nums.
example_explanation: First two elements should be 2.
hints:
• Use two pointers
• Move non-val elements to front
• Track count of non-val elements

title: Find the Index of the First Occurrence in a String
description: Given two strings needle and haystack, return the index of the first occurrence of needle in haystack, or -1 if needle is not part of haystack.
constraints:
• 1 <= haystack.length, needle.length <= 10^4
• haystack and needle consist of only lowercase English characters
example_explanation: First occurrence of "sad" is at index 0.
hints:
• Use built-in string search or implement KMP
• Sliding window approach also works
• Check for match at each position

title: Divide Two Integers
description: Given two integers dividend and divisor, divide two integers without using multiplication, division, and mod operator. The integer division should truncate toward zero. Return the quotient after dividing dividend by divisor.
constraints:
• -2^31 <= dividend, divisor <= 2^31 - 1
• divisor != 0
example_explanation: 10/3 = 3.33.. which truncates to 3.
hints:
• Use bit manipulation and subtraction
• Double the divisor until it exceeds dividend
• Handle overflow and negative numbers carefully

title: Substring with Concatenation of All Words
description: You are given a string s and an array of strings words of the same length. Return all starting indices of substring(s) in s that is a concatenation of each word in words exactly once, in any order, and without any intervening characters.
constraints:
• 1 <= s.length <= 10^4
• 1 <= words.length <= 5000
• 1 <= words[i].length <= 30
• s and words[i] consist of lowercase English letters
example_explanation: Substring starting at 0 is "barfoo" and at 9 is "foobar".
hints:
• Use sliding window with hash map
• Track word frequencies
• Window size is len(words) * len(words[0])
